Dear [Patient's Name],

I hope this letter finds you well and on the path to a swift recovery. We are writing to summarize the course of your care during your recent hospital stay from March 10, 2024, to March 12, 2024.

On the evening of March 10, 2024, you were admitted to the hospital with chest pain and shortness of breath. An ECG revealed ST elevation in the v5-6 leads, indicating a possible ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) involving the left main coronary artery. As per our local hospital guidelines, treatment for STEMI was initiated immediately. However, due to the inability to contact the cardiac catheterization lab and receive an immediate response from the cardiology team, we continued monitoring and managing your condition as per protocol.

Your initial lab investigations on March 11 confirmed elevated Troponin T levels, indicating myocardial infarction. We provided treatment according to emergency cardiac care protocols, including the administration of aspirin (324 mg, chewed for rapid absorption), oxygen therapy, and nitroglycerin for persistent chest pain. Morphine was administered as needed for pain relief.

By the night of March 12, your chest pain had resolved, and your clinical status had significantly improved. Consequently, you expressed a desire to be discharged, which was deemed appropriate by the attending medical team.

Upon discharge, please remember to adhere to the medication guidelines provided to you. If you experience any recurrent symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, or other concerns, do not hesitate to contact your healthcare provider or return to the hospital immediately.

We recommend a follow-up visit with your primary care physician or cardiologist within the next week to ensure your recovery continues smoothly and to discuss any long-term treatment plans.

It was our privilege to care for you, and we wish you a full and speedy recovery. Should you have any questions or require further assistance, please do not hesitate to contact us.

Warm regards,
